column1: Kristinehamn is a locality and the seat of Kristinehamn Municipality

Kristinehamn is situated by the shores of lake Vänern  where the small rivers Varnan and Löt drain into the lake. It has a harbour and is a railroad and road transportation center. Nearby towns include Karlskoga and Karlstad and are located exactly in the middle of Oslo
column2: Stockholm and Gothenburg with 250 km to each of them.

column1: The location has had a resident population for centuries
column2: at least since the stone age. The town was then built alongside the bridge over river Varnan. Its name was Broo (or Bro) until 1642

column1: Kristinehamn got a Royal Charter for the first time in 1582 but lost it in 1584
column3: and changed its name in honour of the monarch Queen Christina of Sweden. It thus qualifies as one of Sweden's historical cities. Its city arms were designated with a bojort
column4: which is a Dutch ship in use in the 17th century.

column1: By the shores of lake Vänern stands this 15 meter high Pablo Picasso statue at 59.273279°N 14.051522°E﻿ / 59.273279; 14.051522 since 1965. The statue was designed by Picasso
column2: but built and inaugurated without him visiting the construction site. Picasso never visited Kristinehamn. Its 15 meters make it the tallest Picasso Sculpture in the world (except for the Chicago sculpture that is actually 15.2 Meters in height.)

column1: Kristinehamn Church  (Kristinehamns kyrka) was designed by professor Carl Georg Brunius (1793–1869) and was first opened in 1858. The church also has a museum in the sanctuary gallery that is worth a visit because of its unique architecture.
